reviewText:
The Holy Grail of gaming is the game you can play forever. To some that is the make-your-own-rules sandbox RPG, to others it is the strategy game where all playthroughs are similar yet unique. In the latter category the championship title holder has always been Civilization. The original design is so strong yet adaptable that it has been able to sustain an entire series that continues its triumphant march through history with V.

From one settler and one warrior begins global conquest. So it has been and so shall it be but the ways to supremacy have never been as varied or as satisfying as they are here. Brave New World finally made the cultural strategy fun and the introduction of city-states in the base game did the same for diplomacy. Victory through science has changed the least and while the same could be said for the military victory it does not apply to actual combat itself. Stack of Doom, the most bizarre design oversight in the franchise, has been done away with. In its place is a mechanic similar to other hex-based strategy games but while it does not break new ground as such it fits in here perfectly and makes annexing the pacifists quite entertaining to do. Unfortunately the vassalization from IV is not possible here. Warmongering also brings very serious diplomatic penalties, more serious than ever before, and bullies will find themselves completely isolated from the diplomatic stage.

The cultural system introduced in the previous Civilization has been refined and is my personal favorite aspect of V. Accumulating culture expands the city limits which the workers can work on but also allows you to pick social policies that give empire-wide bonuses. It is of course best to plan the way to victory as early as possible and build social structure accordingly but there is also something of a role-playing feel to it as well. Whether warlord, plutocrat or tolerant diplomat, all feels satisfying to be. Another way of tailoring your empire to your liking is religion. As your cities accumulate faith you advance in religion, at first choosing a basic Pantheon belief (God-King"
recommended: then having a Great Prophet found a religion and picking your boons from the ones still available and so on. Religion is not mandatory for victory but can make it much easier. For example an aggressive leader could use faith points to purchase holy warriors
hoursPlayed: then use religion to finance the resultant army upkeep through tithes and finally pick a belief that gives a combat bonus around enemy cities that your missionaries have converted beforehand. Brave New World also added a caravan system which is the best way to make money by far
voteText: perhaps "too best"
helpfulPercent: but still an interesting addition to the tried and true.\n\nMaking the role-playing aspects even more deeper are the various civilizations themselves. All get an unique ability and a pair of unique units and/or buildings. The list is by far the most expansive in any Civ yet and includes debutants like Poland or Brazil. To my amazement all cultures feel logically designed and balanced to play as. Sometimes the abilites are much more particular than in other cases meaning that some cultures are easier to triumph as but that only adds to meaningful challenge. The Mayans have an especially amusing ability called The Long Count that gives them a free Great Person every 394 years
votesHelpful: at the end of their calendar cycle.\n\nMenus and lists are universally clear and all necessary information is easy to find. You can also activate the DLCs you want
votesTotal: put in mods from the Workshop and customize many other things as well
votesFunny: from the map to AI personalities. Something Civilization has always had that no fantasy or sci-fi game can never surpass is the richness of lore
commentsCount: or in this case
column16: actual human history. No amount of imagination can come up with anything stranger or more interesting and it makes the game more welcoming in ways too many to count. A special recognition of achievement goes to the in-game Civilopedia that is so clearly and informatively written that sometimes it is relaxing to take a break from empire-building and read about history
column17: from pottery to Napoleon to a technology called The Internet.\n\nCivilization V is so rich and deep that writing about it always glosses some things over and stresses others too much which is fitting since the same applies to actual civilization as well. The complete game is indeed the most perfect Civ yet made and one of the finest eternal games in existence. Whether one wants to spend a night or two or all of them playing
column18: Civ V will provide mental stimulation as long as it is needed."

reviewText:
Built an Empire Kept world peace for over 1,000 years. Kept every nation rich and then the worst happened... People started building up militaries pushing them towards everyones border. I started trading away EVERYTHING i had to every one to keep from starting wars but then it happened....

Everyone went to war agaisnt one another and they all asked me for help. But i a simple super power with only aircraft and enough ships to protect myself but not invade was asked to fight everyong else by everyone. I had to decline and they all got ♥♥♥♥♥♥ at me. So i knew the end was coming but i wasnt going to go down like a city state.

I Started to invest in ground troops had Enough Death robots and Tanks and men to start invasions once they sent theirs at me and lost them due to my over whelming navy. I sent my troops to other parts of the world and one by one i captured and razed cities to the ground ignoring the capitales so they would still be around.

In the end everyone was back to just their starter city i freeded 6 nations and they were permantly my ally and friend. They never asked of me or hated me. Everything was back to normal people forgot the wars and built up empires and started to push out only this time they were friendly and nice.. Then it happened i got sneak attacked by another nation with nuclear arms and a hidden invasion force.

I lost half my civ and my capital but it didnt end. My 6 allies that i freed from the grave came to my defense and took out the invaders and helped me reclaim my land even giving my back my captured cities. I was a Super Power for over 10k years 'in game' and was reduced to a common city state level of influence. I started to rebuild and reexpand but a friend stole my land... He built a city on my land and i couldnt do anything about it until i got ♥♥♥♥♥♥ and took it back ending a friendship that lasted the ages..  This is just a small part of what this game has to offer.  ♥♥♥♥ing get it

reviewText:
This game is remarkable. Get this instead of the garbage that is Beyond Earth.

For those unfamiliar with this series, you pick a great civilization from history (Rome, China, Aztecs, England, ETC) and start with a single city. From there you will be playing for hours and hours (as games take a very long time, and it's fun as hell) exploring, making allies and enemies with the other civilizations, going to war, making more cities, managing resources to fuel your conquest, and racing against the other players in an attempt to win the game. Winning the game can be complex, as there are several ways to win. You can win by destroying the other civs through war, win scientifically by making it into space, culturally with social policies, or diplomatically with the united nations.

The game is very dynamic, not a single playthrough is at all similiar with another, leading to great fun that never tires.

The pros? Too many to list. The game is beautifully structured and well thought out.

The cons? Buggy AI, but not really an issue.

Point is, rather reading this wordy review you should be buying this game, with all the expansion packs. I cannot praise this game enough.
voteText: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Sid Meier's Civilization V is really one of the best strategy games of the genre and the best of its series. Clocking in countless hours, I still find myself frequently playing the game and still discovering new content and strategies that only add more depth to the game.

Graphics
+ Detailed enviroments and units
+ Beautiful terrain and water

Gameplay

+ Dozens of civilizations to play as with unique units and traits
+ Hours of features that bring you back to play
+ Not to diffucult of a learning-curve
+ Easy to set up multiplay that allows you to play easily with friends
- Buggy multiplayer

Overall this is one of the best games I have in my library and one of the best I have ever played. I also recommend others in the series as they add their own unique spin on the genre and provide even more unique gameplay.

9/10

Winning the game can be complex, as there are several ways to win. You can win by destroying the other civs through war, win scientifically by making it into space, culturally with social policies, or diplomatically with the united nations.

The game is very dynamic, not a single playthrough is at all similiar with another, leading to great fun that never tires.

The pros? Too many to list. The game is beautifully structured and well thought out.

The cons? Buggy AI, but not really an issue.

Point is, rather reading this wordy review you should be buying this game, with all the expansion packs. I cannot praise this game enough.

reviewText: 4K fans will love this game; those from an RTS background looking to try out turn-based strategy will be disappointed in the fact that combat victories are essentially impossible in games of more than 4 players/NPCs. The game is too heavily slanted towards other victory acheivements; it is too difficult to conquer cities and happiness makes a global conquest strategy through military might nigh impossible because eventually your armies will simply be spread too thin and enemies will too easily be able to reinforce their positions on large maps. I still recommend it though for 4K people, but coming from a Command & Conquer/Starcraft/Warcraft background, I can't get out of the conquest mindset and the other strategies aren't to my taste. If you enjoy the longer, slower-paced games which involve meticulously building up a civilization, this is one of the best games out there for that.

reviewText:
I've been playing Sid Meier games since I was 11, I bought Civ V about two years ago and have been loving it since.  I've invested a lot of time into the game and I have to say its by far my favorite strategy game of all-time.  Though the AI is stupid and conducts repetitive actions majority of the time and the difficultly doesnt change anything (at least for me, whatever difficulty I play on, I am always in the lead a few Era's.)

The only downside to the game, is the diplomatic functions and the missing ability to ask the AI's for support the same way they can.  Fortunately there is mods for both of these downsides but sadly it disables achivements which for me at least, is a moderately big part of the experience for me.

The game looks stunning and the colors pop.  Gameplay is smooth and enjoyable.  I recommend this game to any one who loves simulation, strategy, history, and action.  You can kill a good 5 hours playing a quick match so if you are ever needing to kill time at an airport or at your boring grandmothers house but you only brought your laptop with you, Civ is the game for you.

reviewText:
For those who like the genre, it is a step-up on the previous installments regarding (obviously) additional options, especially with the 2 expansions, Gods and Kings and Brave New World.

The social policies changes and the introduction of religion options and city-states and interaction with said city-states, were the biggest changes in the game in terms of different things to do. That said, i think there's still room for improvement on additional options you might have in terms of policy choosing, etc.

The economy system is also a bit different from previous installments, a bit richer, and i think the military aspect of the game improved a lot in terms of tactics. Granted, still room for improvement there, but much less 'cheesy' tactics like stacking 20 units in a tile, for instance. You now really need to know where to position your units, and use choke points, etc. to your advantage. Much more 'chess-like' than 'win-by-more-numbers'.

Some of the different win conditions have also gained more depth, especially the diplomatic / cultural victory.

The mods from the steam workshop are also insanely rich, giving you even more customization / replay value to the game.

Lastly, the graphics have obviously also improved a lot, with a lot more detail, even though, at least for me, that's the least concerning aspect of a game such as this.

Its downsides (as usual) mostly revolve around the need to have a sufficiently good pc to handle the burden of loading times, etc., as it is quite heavy on your pc.
Most games also tend to have a mid-game era which is quite stale, where pretty much nothing happens regardless of whether you're far ahead, far behind or even with the majority of the other civs.
AI is also something that still hasn't improved as much as i would have liked. It is either too aggressive or too passive, but not really playing intelligently, regardless of difficulty level, but rather as usual, gaining more bonuses to make up fo the lack of actual Intelligence on the Artificial Intelligence part.

So, breaking it down:

Pros:
- Even more tech / social options, richer interaction with city-states;
- Religion now plays a big role in the game;
- More depth in cultural / diplomatic win conditions;
- Improved combat / tactical aspect of the game;
- Improved mod / customization in steam workshop;
- Lots of replay value;
- Better graphics.

Cons:
- Game can be quite the resource-hog on your pc, regardless of having or not a good one.
- Some games can turn out to be stale for quite some time, depending on specific spawn points, etc.
- Could still have improved social policy choosing, despite the huge improvements on that aspect.
- AI's actual intelligence part hasn't really improved, in my opinion.


TL;DR:

A solid 8.5 out of 10, whether you're new to the franchise, or have played them all since the very first pixelated Civilization 1, like myself. Would honestly give it more, if the loading times were faster. I don't mind putting in the hours playing the game, it's just a bit bothersome knowing that a somewhat significant part of those hours are spent waiting, rather than playing.

reviewText:
Sid Meier's Civilization V is a turn-based strategy game, falling into the 4x genre of video games. It is the Fifth game of the series and was released in 2010. You play as the leader of a civilization, such as; Ramses, Washington, Khan, and must develop your civilization to grow and settle new area's, including through diplomatic, economic, or military means. There are several conditions for victory you can play toward, and each turn represents several years in your civilizations time. Civilization V also has a new feature known as City-States, individual settlements, who are independent of the computer controlled civilizations, and operate as their own entities, making alliances, declaring war etc.

Having had limited experience with the series, only playing Civ 3 for less than an hour several years ago, I came into Civ V with little expectations. I found it to be relatively easy to learn, the tutorial process and advisor tips help shorten the learning curve, and is actually fun. I found the AI to be interesting, as each player civilization and city-state has it's own personality. I haven't tried any of the Downloadable content, such as; Gods and Kings, or Brave New World; However, I can assume they only add to the fun you will have with Civilization V.

Normally, I don't care for turn-based games and prefer real-time strategy, but Civilization V was a pleasant surprise. It was easy to learn, graphically, it looks a lot like the Total War games. If you like turn-based strategy games in the 4x genre, give this one a try.

reviewText:
If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:
1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:
1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

reviewText:
Strategy fanatics have lost hundreds of hours of their lives to Sid Meier's beguiling creations over the years, and they should prepare to lose hundreds more. Civilization V is yet another glistening example of turn-based bliss that will keep you up long past your bedtime. It exercises its power over your mind using many of the tricks the series has long been known for: varied ways of accomplishing your goal of world domination, the thrill of expanding a paltry city into a bustling empire, and the suspense of venturing into unknown territory. The latest Civilization game takes those basics and layers onto them new features that make moment-to-moment gameplay feel more dynamic than in the past. Most noticeably, the square grids of previous Civilization games have been jettisoned in favor of hexagons that nicely accommodate the other most consequential transformations: Military units can no longer be stacked, and ranged units can fire from multiple tiles away. The tactical combat that rises from these modifications is a lot of fun and makes warfare a lot more exciting than in Civ games of yore. AI quirks and a few other minor issues become apparent the more you play, but these are wholly forgivable foibles in an attractive and sophisticated game that constantly begs you to remain at your keyboard for just one more turn.

First, here is a quick primer for newcomers. Civilization V, like previous games in the series, is about leading a nation through the eras of history, starting with a single city and expanding across the map. At the outset of any given game, you select a leader (in this case, one of 18, or 19 if you purchased the special edition from Steam), each of whom possesses a particular benefit that disposes his or her civilization to a particular style of play. Americans get a range of sight bonus; the Siamese get diplomatic bonuses with miniature nations new to the series called city-states; the English get naval perks; and so forth. From here, you collect resources; make deals with other civilizations; manage your economy; and go to war and attack the cities of your enemies when the time is right. There are four main ways to win a typically lengthy game of Civilization V. You could dominate through military means and defeat every civilization's capital city. You could be the first to gun through the technology tree and build the parts necessary for a spaceship that whisks you away to Alpha Centauri. You could ally with nations and city-states across the globe and win a diplomatic victory via a vote at the United Nations. Or you might become the cultural envy of the world by developing a large number of government policies and researching a mysterious undertaking known as the Utopia Project. There is also a fifth victory condition: possess the highest score when the turn limit has been reached.

Whether Civ is new to you or not, it's easy to appreciate the newest game's user-friendly interface, which makes figuring out what to do next a breeze, meaning more of your time is spent strategizing and less of it is spent fumbling around. The organized nested menus are intuitive and easy to get used to, and Civ V does a good job of only displaying vital information on the screen while making other information easily available with just a few clicks. A single action button leads you through every aspect of your turn. If a unit is waiting for orders, the button says so, and clicking it takes you to the unit in question. If it's time to research a new technology, you click the button and it opens the research menu. There are a few aspects of the interface that could have been cleaned up. Switching between a city's production menu and the production queue is needlessly clunky, and the diplomatic overview doesn't label the tiny icons indicating what luxury resources other civilizations are producing. But most of the time, you always have the information you need when you need it, and neophytes should never feel in the dark.

A few of Civilization IV's features have been eliminated--most notably, religion and espionage--though many players aren't likely to miss them. However, longtime aspects of the series have returned. Your advisors are there if you need a bit of direction, though unit automation and little icons representing each advisor's suggestion in the production menus mean you won't often need to pay them a visit. The exhaustive Civilopedia is only a click away and offers a wealth of information on every aspect of every feature. You still build wonders like the Egyptian pyramids, the hanging gardens, and the Great Wall, which generate the culture resource and provide other tangible benefits, without coming with the turn-by-turn maintenance cost of standard structures. The culture you gain is spent on social policies, which have replaced the governments of Civilization IV. Each time you reach the cultural resource benchmark, you select from the policy list, which is split into multiple policy types, each of which has its own sub-tree. The benefits you reap are cumulative, and while there are certain balancing restrictions in place, you still get a lot of freedom in how you want to progress. The mid- and late-game flexibility make it an excellent addition to the franchise. The first change you'll notice, however, has even more impact on Civilization V: The map is divided into hexagons rather than squares.

The move to hexagons sets the stage for Civilization V's tactical combat. In the past, you could stack units into one army of doom (or a few armies) that rolled across the map. Now, with the exception of special units (the great general, for example) and workers, units cannot occupy the same space. As a result, you must be extremely conscious of each unit's weaknesses and strengths; a unit's position in regards to both its enemies and other friendly units; and whether or not any terrain bonuses apply. There is a rock-paper-scissors relationship among units that further deepens as units level up and you progress through the eras. When units level up, you choose one of several upgrades for them, such as an attack bonus when attacking from flat terrain. As they level up further, the possibilities expand, which means healing bonuses for the unit, as well as neighboring units, or greater degrees of the same enhancements. Helpfully, you can also choose to fully heal the unit when it levels at the expense of choosing another bonus, which is a mighty handy ability that can save a veteran unit from the jaws of defeat. This excellent new system layers tactical combat onto the strategic map, making battles much tenser--and much less abstract. It also encourages you to keep your veteran units alive. And while it costs you a bit of gold, you can also upgrade units into more powerful iterations (a trebuchet into a cannon, for example) when your research path allows it.

Multiplayer games are also a possibility for the most patient players. You can set a turn timer to limit how long players get to consider their next move, but even so, the pace is at the whim of those involved, so matches can get bogged down in the early hours. Luckily, most of the customization options available to you in single-player games are available in multiplayer games as well, so you can keep things moving with the right options activated. Gone are hotseat and e-mail play options, with online and local network play as the only ways to play with others. By nature, Civilization V is a game you enjoy most with friends instead of random strangers, though the simple interface makes it easy to find and join available Internet games.

reviewText:
Civilization V is as much a lateral step away from the complicated nature of Civ IV as it is a step forward in the franchise's vaunted history.

Most importantly, after 18 months, Civ 5 has improved dramatically from the game it was upon release. The AI is improved, key game concepts have been buffed and nerfed, as needed. And there is welcome, but not critical, DLC.

What I love about this version: hex-based game board for more natural movement. No more stacks of doom. Global happiness. No tech trading. Drastically improved AI relations. Improved event notification system means you never miss a beat.

What I dislike: The tech tree has been significantly flattened from Civ 4. Tech and Culture victories are terribly boring to achieve: hunker down, press next turn"
date: repeat 200 times. Overreliance on gold farming to buy off all problems.\n\nOverall - a successful attempt to streamline gameplay without removing core elements. Civ 5 is a success
recommended: and I welcome the coming expansion(s)."

reviewText: Honestly? Yes, I do reccomend it to any MMO Board game fans or Strategy players out there. Civ V is a time-eating game, it's a game you can casually playand check your emails/facebook while playing, but thatdoesnt mean the game isn't intense, whenever I sit down to play a game of Civ for a few minutes, I end up spending my whole day building my civillization. This game also has great tool-tips and UI. I mastered the game without the need of tutuorial but there areadvisor-in-game diologues that explain everything. (These can be disabled.) In all fairness, I give this game a 8.5 out of 10, buy this game, it's worth every single penny.

reviewText: This is a vast game, with the highest replay value of any other I have ever played. The differences among civilizations range from slim to huge, and they all have a very unique style of gameplay. Put in the many factors that can be modified before a game session, such as map size and resource abundance, and you'll find yourself living with this game for a long time. Big points for the soundtrack and graphics as well. The AI is really well adjusted too, compared to older versions of Civilization. It is now possible to actually stand a chance playing in the hardest settings and still feels rewarding if you lose and yet tried your best.\n\nThere is nothing left to say other than... play this game!!! Oh and get the expansions too!

reviewText: Great game, if you have time.  You could easily spend 48 hours straight on this game.  Workshop support is fun, though not all of the mods really work that well.  Also, seems to have optimization issues, can run on almost any comp within the last few years on low, but high seems to have trouble on even dedicated gaming comps.  Also the more turns have passed, the more time it takes for the cpus to take their turn.  Like I would get over a minuite sometimes.\n\nAlso, the game isn't quite complete without the dlc sadly.  The dlc adds a great number of features, fixes, ect, but should have been a free update.  You can however get it pretty cheap if you check the steam sales.
